search_result.title: Ohio basketball coaches express concern over new RPI rankings
search_result.text:
Central Ohio high school basketball coaches already were anticipating a tournament draw unlike any other, thanks to a new ratings system that will determine the seeding for each team.

Then they saw the first weekly rankings last week and curiosity turned to concern, if not outright frustration.

Olentangy Orange and Delaware Hayes held the top two spots in the district in Division I boys, but, among other surprises, two teams with statewide and even national schedules in Reynoldsburg and Pickerington Central were 19th and 21st, respectively. In the latest rankings Wednesday, Orange (12-0) and Delaware (12-1) remained first and second, while Reynoldsburg (8-4) was 17th and Central (8-4) was 22nd.

search_result.title: Coach Danny Rocco disputes FCS reasons for UNH's selection over ...
search_result.text:
New Hampshire’s preference over Delaware as being tournament-worthy came down to UNH wins over Elon, a CAA foe the Blue Hens didn’t play, and a 1-9 FBS team, according to the FCS committee chairman.

Delaware was not selected for the 24-team NCAA bracket Sunday, which irked the Blue Hens primarily because Colonial Athletic Association rival New Hampshire was included for the 14th straight year.

“Based on the pool of candidates, this team deserved an opportunity to participate in the postseason and we were denied that opportunity,” Delaware coach Danny Rocco said Monday.

NFL: Eagles clobber Cowboys

COLLEGES: DelState's Carter fired

Delaware and New Hampshire each went 7-4 overall and 4-3 in the league, but didn’t play each other.

Against common foes, Delaware went 4-2 to UNH’s 3-3. The Blue Hens lost to James Madison and Towson while the Wildcats fell against JMU, Stony Brook and Albany, the latter a 15-0 defeat Saturday one week after the Hens handled the Great Danes 22-3 at Delaware Stadium.

Delaware was also above New Hampshire in the computer-generated Jeff Sagarin Ratings, had a better strength of schedule and was ranked 21st to UNH’s 31st in the NCAA’s Simple Ratings System, similar to the Ratings Percentage Index used in basketball and other sports.

“We were, without a doubt, the fourth team in our league,” said Rocco, referring to other CAA qualifiers JMU, Stony Brook and Elon. “There was no statistical data that would have supported a thought that there was a fourth team more worthy, so I really have struggled with that.”

Wofford athletic director and FCS selection committee chairman Richard Johnson, in a telephone interview with The News Journal, pointed out the Blue Hens’ blemishes in comparison to UNH.

“They didn’t have an FBS win,” Johnson said, referring to the Hens’ 27-0 loss Sept. 9 at Virginia Tech, a Top 25 team then and now.

“The two losses they had were to teams just recently that did not have winning records and that hurt them. In our RACs [regional advisory committees] they were a little bit below the teams in the field that made it. That’s not the determinant. That’s a factor that we look at.”

Most would agree Delaware’s losses at Towson 18-17 on Oct. 28 and Villanova 28-7 on Saturday were inexcusable for a team with tournament aspirations. But when Rocco learned late Saturday afternoon New Hampshire had also lost at Albany, his first thought was, he said Sunday, “We are back in this thing.” Numerous other losses by tournament hopefuls had put Delaware squarely on the bubble for tourney selection.

But the committee preferred UNH, giving significant weight to its 22-12 win at Georgia Southern on Sept. 9. The Statesmen, members of the Sun Belt Conference, got their first win 52-0 Saturday against South Alabama. South Dakota and Nicholls State were actually the final two teams to get in and Austin Peay and Delaware were the first two out, Johnson said.

Ironically, last year Albany had a 7-4 record and wins over UNH and FBS Buffalo but didn’t make the field.

“They had an FBS win over Georgia Southern,” Johnson said of this year’s Wildcats, “and then, on top of that, they beat Elon when Elon was number six in our rankings, so it literally comes down to those differences.”

New Hampshire handed Elon its first CAA loss 16-6 on Nov. 11, with Elon subsequently losing to JMU and finishing third in the league behind the Dukes and Stony Brook, which didn’t play JMU or Elon.

Asked about Delaware’s superior record against common foes, Johnson, oddly, replied, “Delaware didn’t play Elon or UNH, so that conference record is skewed in that regard.

“We don’t look at Sagarin,” Johnson added. “We do look at the Simple Ratings System, but Simple Ratings is one tool in the tool box. If you look at UNH, they had an FBS win. Their quality win over Elon was, at that time, a better quality win than the one Delaware had over Stony Brook.”

Delaware won 24-20 at Stony Brook on Oct. 7. Stony Brook ended up ahead of Elon in the CAA standings, Sagarin Ratings and the Simple Ratings System.

The committee’s failure to place greater emphasis on the Simple Ratings System baffled Rocco.

For leagues that had multiple bids, FCS selectors followed SRS rankings in choosing Missouri Valley, Southern and Big Sky conference teams for the NCAA playoffs. For the Southland, they did until opting for Nicholls State, which was 28th, over McNeese State, which was 19th. But Nicholls beat McNeese.

Among CAA schools, however, Delaware was 21st in the SRS to UNH’s 31st. Richmond (6-5) was actually ahead of UNH, too, at 25th.

“In what world are you living in where that is an acceptable reality?” said Rocco.

A week after winning at Georgia Southern, New Hampshire lost 51-26 at Holy Cross, a fact that seemed to have been ignored by selectors.

Holy Cross went 4-7 overall and 3-3 in the Patriot League, whose champion, Lehigh, finished an unsightly 5-6.

Athletic directors Marty Scarano of New Hampshire and Nathan Pine of Holy Cross both serve on the selection committee.

“Marty has been as objective a committee member as we’ve had,” Johnson said, adding that members whose schools are being discussed must leave the room. “ . . . Nobody was voting New Hampshire because of Marty. They voted based on the criteria we have in that manual and how those teams fit into that.”

Delaware and New Hampshire were competing with a bunch of other 7-4 teams that also lost Saturday for at-large spots, including South Dakota, Furman, Northern Arizona, Montana, plus 9-2 Monmouth that lost Saturday and Nicholls State that fell Thursday to finish 8-3.

Johnson referred to it as “The Saturday Massacre.”

“Everybody got beat,” he said. “It muddied the waters, made everything even that much harder. I’ve been on this committee for five years and this was, by far, not even close, to being the toughest one ever,” Johnson said.

Two Saturday winners -- Eastern Washington (7-4) and Austin Peay (8-4) -- were also viewed as candidates.

In addition to UNH, teams among the aforementioned that made the field were Northern Arizona, South Dakota, Furman, Monmouth and Nicholls State.

“When I came in Sunday morning,” Rocco said, “and I did all the research, there was nothing that would lead me to think that we would not be in the field. The CAA merits four teams.”

The CAA got its quartet, but Delaware wasn’t one-fourth.

Contact Kevin Tresolini at ktresolini@delawareonline.com. Follow on Twitter @kevintresolini.

search_result.title: Where do Delaware congressional candidates stand on gun control?
search_result.text:
Adam Duvernay

The News Journal

On Tuesday, The News Journal contacted each of the six candidates seeking to fill the congressional seat soon to be vacated by John Carney to ask their stance on gun control legislation on the federal level.

By Thursday afternoon, all six had answered a series of five questions on legislation, enforcement and the larger gun violence debate. Their full answers were sent in emails and appear in their entirety below.

Sean Barney:

Q: Is gun violence a problem in the nation that can be addressed through legislation? If yes, should that legislation be at the federal level, the state level or both? If no, what is the solution you see that best reduces the frequency of gun violence episodes? What do you think gun laws should be?

A: When I was policy director to our [Gov. Jack Markell], we passed a smart package of gun safety measures that closed longstanding loopholes in our gun laws here in Delaware. But state laws alone won’t fix the problem because most firearms used in crimes come from out of state.

That is why I am the only candidate in this race to have prepared a comprehensive policy proposal for addressing gun violence at the federal level. My plan would require universal background checks, ban military-style assault weapons, make gun trafficking a federal offense, and close loopholes to keep guns out of the hands of domestic abusers and terrorists. We also need to address the root causes of violence, which is why my plan calls for support for a new and comprehensive youth violence reduction partnership in Delaware, drawing on examples from successful programs in cities like Philadelphia and Richmond, CA. You can read my full online at seanbarneyforcongress.com/AddressingGunViolence or by texting the word “Sean” to 86329.

Q: Why would a Congressman or Congresswoman from Delaware be a good voice to add to the national debate about gun violence? What is your personal connection to the issue? Are you a gun owner, and what is your personal experience handling/purchasing firearms? What is your standing with the NRA?

A: As someone who survived being shot through the neck, the issue of gun violence is personal to me. But while I volunteered to join the Marines – knowing full well the danger that might entail – no one volunteers to have their neighborhood turned into a war zone.

The NRA can’t accuse me of being weak on guns. I shot guns for sport as a boy, I became a marksman in boot camp in preparation to serve my company, I’ve been shot at, and I’ve been shot. I know the difference between a gun designed for hunting or personal protection, and one designed to inflict the greatest amount of damage possible. I have the credibility that’s required to accomplish common sense reform.

Q: What are the failures/successes on a national and state level in the wake of the Sandy Hook massacre? What should national/state gun laws look like today, and can you point to a specific vote or bill in Congress you’d have supported/opposed which demonstrates your point of view?

A: I’m proud that when I was policy director to Governor Markell, we responded to the tragedy at Sandy Hook by passing common sense gun violence legislation here in Delaware. But 61% of guns seized by Delaware law enforcement come from out of state. That’s why we need action on the federal level and why I’m the only candidate in this race to put out a comprehensive policy proposal to address gun violence.

My comprehensive gun violence proposal is much too long to relate here, but you can read it in full online at seanbarneyforcongress.com/AddressingGunViolence or by texting the word “Sean” to 86329. As one specific example, I would join Senator Carper and Senator Coons in advocating for legislation like the Denying Firearms and Explosives to Dangerous Terrorists Act, which would prohibit those on the Federal Terrorism Watchlist from buying firearms or explosives.

Q:Are Americans numb to violence? Is there a culture changes that has to take place, and what would that shift look like in terms of laws, public action and education? Are episodes of mass violence the “new normal,” and would citizens be safer with more or less access to firearms?

A: Too many in Washington have become numb to the senseless violence sweeping our nation. Weapons that are built for Marines fighting overseas have no place on the streets of Wilmington, and news headlines that sound like a dispatch from a reporter embedded with a platoon in Fallujuh should not be coming out of places like Newtown, Aurora, or Santa Barbara.

That’s why we need leaders with credibility on this issue and a proven track record of getting the job done. As someone who has handled firearms, who has been shot at, and who has been shot through the neck while serving my country in Iraq, I have the credibility needed to get Washington working again.

Q: If you were sitting in Congress, what do you believe your role could/would be on the issue of gun violence? Where does it fit into your list of priorities? Is this a partisan issue? How can you make a difference?

A: I will make addressing gun violence in Delaware and across our nation a top priority in Congress. No one ever asked us in the Marines if we were Democrats or Republicans; they just expected us to work together to get the job done for the good of the country. That’s the attitude I’ll take when tackling this issue. As someone who has handled guns, both for sport and in service of my country, and as someone who has been shot, I have the credibility needed to break the gridlock in Washington and get results. We did it at the state level when I was policy director to Governor Markell and I will fight to get results at the federal level when I am elected to Congress.

Rose Izzo (responses sent through campaign spokesman Kevin Izzo):

The Izzo campaign did not answer The News Journal's questions in a format which designated answers for particular questions. Her camp's full response to the five questions is as follows:

Unfortunately the gun issue is driven by lobbyists, special interests and yellow journalism.

Average citizens, like Rose Izzo and her neighbors are concerned with national security, securing our borders, job opportunity for Americans and supporting our military and veterans.

As the first Congresswoman elected in the state of Delaware, Rose Izzo's focus will be on the needs of our citizens, not lobbyists and political sugar daddies.

Grandstanding on poll tested issues is no solution for Delaware.

Rose Izzo's solution: A job that pays a living wage.

Rose Izzo understand how hard it is to live on a small income and the fear that there is more money going out than there is coming in. This is why Rose Izzo is in favor of better jobs with higher wages, and the quality education needed to improve our economy.

Rose Izzo is very familiar with the safe handling and operation of home protection devices.

Nicknamed "Pistol Packing Rosie", Rose Izzo had the honor of receiving special training using high capacity handguns and semiautomatic rifles.

Care for our veterans & military personnel trump meaningless gun legislation everyday.

It's on record that retuning Wounded Warriors are unemployed, homeless, hungry and suicidal.

Let's help them first, before flushing our second amendment down the toilet.

Mike Miller:

Q: Is gun violence a problem in the nation that can be addressed through legislation? If yes, should that legislation be at the federal level, the state level or both? If no, what is the solution you see that best reduces the frequency of gun violence episodes? What do you think gun laws should be?

A: Yes I believe gun violence is a problem in our nation, legislation should be enacted at the federal level with a mandate to state and local levels. Federal, State, and local government has to work hand and hand to implement and solve this issue.

Q: Why would a Congressman or Congresswoman from Delaware be a good voice to add to the national debate about gun violence? What is your personal connection to the issue? Are you a gun owner, and what is your personal experience handling/purchasing firearms? What is your standing with the NRA?

A: We need a congressman who will take a practical approach to solve gun control, I believe there are to many men and woman in congress who are worried about upsetting the apple cart, (the NRA) or losing there house of representative or senate seat. Over half of them are afraid they might lose there campaign contribution. I do not own any guns, rifles, automatic weapons or assault rifles. Not sure what standing I would have with the NRA.

Q: What are the failures/successes on a national and state level in the wake of the Sandy Hook massacre? What should national/state gun laws look like today, and can you point to a specific vote or bill in Congress you’d have supported/opposed which demonstrates your point of view?

A: Some Americans think you are trying to take there guns, this is not the case, when the Second Amendment came about our fore fathers did not think about assault rifles, ak 47's, machine guns. There primary focus was to give you the right to bear arms and protect yourself and your family. The weapons that existed then was muskets, hand guns and other various weapons. This Amendment right was not for todays laws and weapons. The success is, I believe the American people are beginning to realize that something has to be done, and now there is some type of dialog.

Q:Are Americans numb to violence? Is there a culture changes that has to take place, and what would that shift look like in terms of laws, public action and education? Are episodes of mass violence the “new normal,” and would citizens be safer with more or less access to firearms?

A: No Americans are not numb to violence. Episodes of mass violence is not the new normal, at least I pray not.

Q: If you were sitting in Congress, what do you believe your role could/would be on the issue of gun violence? Where does it fit into your list of priorities? Is this a partisan issue? How can you make a difference?

A: We need real comprehensive reform on gun control and take a hard relook at what the second amendment guarantees us. I am for a ban on assault rifles and machine guns, you may own 1 assault rifle but not 2,3,4 or 5. This is a partisan issue. This is priority of mine and ranks in my top

Hans Reigle:

Q: Is gun violence a problem in the nation that can be addressed through legislation? If yes, should that legislation be at the federal level, the state level or both? If no, what is the solution you see that best reduces the frequency of gun violence episodes? What do you think gun laws should be?

A: Law abiding citizens are able to own firearms for protection and sport in accordance with the Second Amendment. Since 2007, the number of concealed handgun permits has risen and yet murder rates have fallen. In Congress, I would support H.R. 923-The Constitutional Concealed Reciprocity Act of 2015, allowing interstate handgun permits.

Q: Why would a Congressman or Congresswoman from Delaware be a good voice to add to the national debate about gun violence? What is your personal connection to the issue? Are you a gun owner, and what is your personal experience handling/purchasing firearms? What is your standing with the NRA?

A: I am a military veteran with twenty years of service, so of course I have a background in handling and using firearms responsibly. I am a gun owner and a NRA member. The Second Amendment protects all other rights.

Q: What are the failures/successes on a national and state level in the wake of the Sandy Hook massacre? What should national/state gun laws look like today, and can you point to a specific vote or bill in Congress you’d have supported/opposed which demonstrates your point of view?

A: Our nation is blessed with many retired military veterans and police officers. They can and should be used in our schools for protection. We have school resource officers and more would be beneficial. An armed teacher or school resource officer could have potentially reduced the number of victims at Sandy Hook. Gun free zones are places where criminals go to shoot people. Sandy Hook and other similar tragedies are also stark evidence that our mental health system is underfunded, understaffed and totally inadequate for today’s complex world. We must also be careful to not characterize terrorist acts (San Bernardino, Fort Hood) as random mass killings.

Q: Are Americans numb to violence? Is there a culture changes that has to take place, and what would that shift look like in terms of laws, public action and education? Are episodes of mass violence the “new normal,” and would citizens be safer with more or less access to firearms?

A: Americans are never numb to violence. This is a particular problem in Delaware where Wilmington has one of highest murder rates in the nation. Often, these crimes go unsolved and this is a terrible burden on the victim’s family. Crimes committed with illegally obtained firearms (and those prohibited from owning a firearm) should be prosecuted and those charges should not be pled down. Additionally, drug dealers with weapons should be prosecuted and low level drug offenders referred to treatment.

Q: If you were sitting in Congress, what do you believe your role could/would be on the issue of gun violence? Where does it fit into your list of priorities? Is this a partisan issue? How can you make a difference?

A: The gun violence issue needs to be de-politicized. It is a concern to everyone. We all agree that mental illness is a major factor in all of the mass shootings. Families need to have resources so that they can report and manage individuals that they know are struggling. Too many times we learn that everyone knew that the person had a problem but there was no one to help. As a Congressman I would support H.R. 2646 –Helping Families in Mental Health Crisis Act of 2015. This bill allows the protected health information of an individual with a serious mental illness to be disclosed to a caregiver under certain conditions. This Act could save many lives.

Lisa Blunt Rochester:

Q: Is gun violence a problem in the nation that can be addressed through legislation? If yes, should that legislation be at the federal level, the state level or both? If no, what is the solution you see that best reduces the frequency of gun violence episodes? What do you think gun laws should be?

A: Addressing gun violence requires local, state and federal involvement. But government action alone is not the answer. We need to be having conversations with our families and communities about suicide prevention and the dangers of gun violence. And maybe most importantly, we need to call this what it is: an epidemic. Over 30,000 Americans die each year from gun violence. To put that in perspective, approximately 40,000 women will die of breast cancer this year in America. And look at the focus, resources, team work and attention that has coalesced, rightly so, around eradicating that disease.

We need to figure out long-term solutions to gun violence by putting much tougher restrictions on who can own a gun and what those guns can do. Any long-term solution needs to be a mix of legislation and educating our culture that gun violence can be prevented.

But, right now, we need to quickly close loopholes that allow criminals to get their hands on guns with ease, increase background checks on everyone who wants to purchase a gun, mandatory reporting for lost and stolen guns, increased funding for mental health treatment and protections for women against abusers and stalkers with guns - including clear relinquishment procedures for gun owners who are later deemed prohibited for whatever reason. I also think it’s irresponsible to prevent government institutions like the CDC from properly studying the root causes of gun violence and understanding the full impact of our current gun policies. We need to address gun violence prevention with the same tools that we would tackle any other serious health problem.

While we're at it, we also should address the role of suicides in gun fatalities by making mental healthcare a priority and working to identify and deliver care to people suffering from mental health conditions. Two-thirds of people in this country who die from guns die by suicide. To quote President Obama when he highlighted this recently, "Our work is to prevent people from hurting themselves."

Q: Why would a Congressman or Congresswoman from Delaware be a good voice to add to the national debate about gun violence? What is your personal connection to the issue? Are you a gun owner, and what is your personal experience handling/purchasing firearms? What is your standing with the NRA?

As a mother of two, I worry about gun violence more than I ever should. The NRA has spent millions of dollars scaring politicians in Washington into inaction. Their money has bought them votes and left far too many families attending funerals instead of graduations. I’m running to stand up to the radicals who are putting campaign contributions above the lives of our children.

Sixty-one percent of guns confiscated in Delaware from 2010-2014 came from other states. Trafficking is a real problem that impacts Delaware disproportionately considering our location along the I-95 corridor, otherwise known as the "iron pipeline" for guns. It’s a national problem and requires federal legislation in order to be properly addressed.



Q: What are the failures/successes on a national and state level in the wake of the Sandy Hook massacre? What should national/state gun laws look like today, and can you point to a specific vote or bill in Congress you’d have supported/opposed which demonstrates your point of view?

A: After the tragedy at Sandy Hook Elementary, the country looked to Congress for a response and something extraordinary happened: nothing at all. Republicans in Congress’ inaction during this time was criminal. In the wake of utter failure in Washington, many states have made progress including Delaware.

It's not politics as usual to praise one's opponents during the course of a campaign, but recently I publicly praised Sean Barney for his plan to reduce gun violence. In addition to Sean's plan, I support doing more to address the role of suicides as stated above. Beau Biden championed legislation in 2013 that would’ve made it harder for the dangerously mentally ill to purchase guns. That bill, HB 88, unfortunately failed. Nearly every member of the State House voted for Beau’s legislation. If elected, I will champion similar legislation in Congress.

In addition, Delaware does not prohibit the sale or transfer of military-style assault weapons or large-capacity ammunition magazines. In past Congresses, I would have voted to extend the Assault Weapons Ban and supported any legislation to ensure that thorough federal background checks are in place for gun purchases and to close loopholes like the gun show loophole at the federal level. In our current Congress, I would’ve supported legislation like the Protecting Domestic Violence and Stalking Victims Act that would prohibit the sale of firearms to people convicted of stalking or those under a restraining order.

Q: Are Americans numb to violence? Is there a culture changes that has to take place, and what would that shift look like in terms of laws, public action and education? Are episodes of mass violence the “new normal,” and would citizens be safer with more or less access to firearms?

A: As I’ve talked to families up and down the state who’ve lost family members and friends, I can tell you we are not numb to gun violence. And there are definite changes that we need to make in our culture along with tougher restrictions on gun ownership and gun trafficking. As a mother, the sheer fact that some consider mass violence a “new normal” is both appalling and sad to me. Our children deserve to grow up in communities where they can feel safe.

If you were sitting in Congress, what do you believe your role could/would be on the issue of gun violence? Where does it fit into your list of priorities? Is this a partisan issue? How can you make a difference?

A: Gun violence isn't simply a partisan issue. It knows no bounds. Americans agree with common sense solutions to gun violence – yet the gun lobby and their allies in Congress continue to stonewall progress and accomplishing anything can seem impossible at times. We need to honor the American spirit of compromise and bring people together towards results-oriented action in Washington. I will be a strong voice for common sense gun violence prevention in Congress.

Bryan Townsend:

Q: Is gun violence a problem in the nation that can be addressed through legislation? If yes, should that legislation be at the federal level, the state level or both? If no, what is the solution you see that best reduces the frequency of gun violence episodes? What do you think gun laws should be?

A: Gun violence has reached epidemic proportions in this country, but I firmly believe bold legislative action is part of the solution to reversing this troubling trend. When we research diseases like cancer, we do so knowing full well that we won't instantly thwart all cancer deaths. But we do it anyway, because we know that over the long term, we will make progress. In the same vein, we know strengthening our gun laws won't suddenly end gun violence or take all guns off the street. Yet over time, we can make real progress.

I am proud to have worked with colleagues in Dover to close Delaware’s gun show loophole and prevent straw purchases. Majority Leader Longhurst, Rep. Osienski and I will be introducing legislation this session to close the delayed transaction loophole, to keep guns out of the hands of individuals like the South Carolina church shooter - who committed that heinous crime with a gun he purchased before the federal government had completed its background check.

Unfortunately, these laws are made less effective if our neighboring states don’t enforce similar regulations. That’s why in Congress, I will fight to expand background checks on all gun purchases and demand the FBI enforce existing laws. I also support strengthening reporting requirements, and lifting the federal ban on gun violence research.

But to drastically reduce the number of Americans killed through senseless gun violence, I believe we need to do even more. We know that the majority of gun deaths in this country are a result of suicide. In Congress, I would push for additional mental health resources as well as responsible gun storage. And we know that urban gun violence cannot be solved without long-term investments in our cities and our citizens, including ensuring every child, regardless of their zip code, has access to a world class education and overcoming other systemic issues like poverty and racial bias.

Q: Why would a Congressman or Congresswoman from Delaware be a good voice to add to the national debate about gun violence? What is your personal connection to the issue? Are you a gun owner, and what is your personal experience handling/purchasing firearms? What is your standing with the NRA?

A: I have never been supported by the NRA and I suspect I never will be. The NRA doesn’t speak for the vast majority of gun owners, who overwhelmingly support universal background checks and other gun safety measures. Delaware is one of the only states in recent years to pass common sense, bi-partisan gun safety legislation and I was proud to be a part of those efforts. I am not a gun owner, but I also believe that's a personal decision. Gun owners are not precluded from fighting for stronger gun laws. In fact, we need their voices to advance these efforts. In Congress I will continue to work with responsible gun owners and gun safety advocates to promote common sense solutions.

Q: What are the failures/successes on a national and state level in the wake of the Sandy Hook massacre? What should national/state gun laws look like today, and can you point to a specific vote or bill in Congress you’d have supported/opposed which demonstrates your point of view?

A: In the wake of the tragedy at Sandy Hook, our biggest failure was partisan gridlock that blocked us from enacting common sense solutions, even though they enjoyed broad popular support. The Senate filibustered a watered-down expansion of background checks. And while politicians paid lip service to the connection between mental health and gun violence, they refused to push for additional funding for mental health services and treatment. I believe Congress should look to Delaware as a model for the types of gun safety legislation that we should enact at the federal level.

Q: Are Americans numb to violence? Is there a culture changes that has to take place, and what would that shift look like in terms of laws, public action and education? Are episodes of mass violence the “new normal,” and would citizens be safer with more or less access to firearms?

A: Sandy Hook, in my mind, was a pivotal event, not just for the sheer horror it represented, but because Congress had a clear choice between taking meaningful action, or ushering in a new normal of gun violence in this country. I think Americans remain outraged over that, and that outrage is renewed each time we see one of these senseless mass shootings unfold on national TV. I do think we're becoming numb to the epidemic of urban gun violence, and that is shameful. We can curb mass shootings with stronger, smarter gun laws, but in order to reduce urban gun violence, we need much more comprehensive progress on the systemic things that drive violence - reducing poverty, reforming our criminal justice system, creating jobs and improving our schools.

Q: If you were sitting in Congress, what do you believe your role could/would be on the issue of gun violence? Where does it fit into your list of priorities? Is this a partisan issue? How can you make a difference?

A: I respect America's firearm tradition and have no interest in taking guns from lawful Americans who own them. I would hope that would be a signal to gun owners and non-owners alike who want to see less blood on our streets to coalesce around me as someone who has the legislative experience in working on common-sense gun-safety laws supported by a diverse group of stakeholders. This is a deeply emotional issue for which progress requires passion. But we also must be willing to consider pragmatic, enforceable legislation that greatly reduces gun violence, knowing we can't eliminate it overnight. We did it in Delaware, and I believe I'm the kind of problem solver who can replicate those efforts in Washington.

search_result.title: Kamala Harris: Inside Joe Biden's grueling search for a vice president
search_result.text:
WASHINGTON – Joe Biden sat in front of a laptop computer at his home office in Wilmington, Delaware. It was around 2:45 p.m Tuesday, and after a months-long search, he was about to reveal one of his biggest campaign decisions to the woman who would make history.

Earlier in the day, Biden called all the women who were finalists in his search for a running mate, including Sen. Tammy Duckworth and Rep. Val Demings. He talked about his decision and ultimately informed them he had chosen someone else.

On the former vice president's desk was a framed photo of the classic cartoon "Hagar the Horrible." In one frame, Hagar, a disheveled Viking, says," Why me?!" In the next, the gods above reply, "Why not?"

The tenuous and drama-filled process that left politicos and voters alike on the edge of their seats was over. He'd made his decision.

He called Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., on Zoom.

Sign-up for Your Vote: Text with the USA TODAY elections team.

"You ready to go to work?" Biden asked her.

"Oh my God. I am so ready to go to work," Harris replied.

'Open and shut':Kamala Harris argues case is clear against Trump in introduction as Biden's running mate

Who is Kamala Harris? A look at Joe Biden's vice presidential running mate

At 4:14 p.m., the Biden campaign broke the news in a mass text message to supporters. Harris, a first-term senator and one of his former Democratic primary opponents, was his long-awaited pick in a move elevating the first Black woman and first Asian American to a major party presidential ticket.

Supporters close to Biden described a "deliberative" process that encompassed several weeks, 11 serious candidates, 120 hours of interviews and, eventually, one name.

"He knew exactly what he was looking for in a VP because he's been a VP," said Rep. Cedric Richmond, D-La., national co-chairman of the Biden campaign. "He was doing an analysis of one, who he could work with; two, who could help him win; three, who could help him govern. And who he clicked with.

"I think he uses the word 'simpatico.' I think he really spent time figuring that out."

You have to win first:What Joe Biden's pick of Kamala Harris tells us about Biden

What comes next:Joe Biden won't travel to Milwaukee for 2020 DNC because of coronavirus concerns

A groundbreaking choice and a secret to keep

The selection of Harris, the daughter of immigrants from Jamaica and India, came amid increasing pressure to choose a woman of color for the Democratic ticket, particularly during a period of heightened racial polarization touched off by the death of George Floyd that triggered nationwide protests over police brutality and racism.

While groundbreaking, the selection of Harris was also conventional, with Biden opting for Washington experience, a senator and ticket balance. Harris is 55 years old, 22 years younger than Biden, 77, and hails from the West Coast in contrast to Biden's East Coast roots.

In the hours before Biden broke the news, he called a number of close advisers and told them the secret talking heads across the country spent weeks speculating about.

Richmond was one of the few. "He was excited. I was certainly excited. And it was, 'Now let's go win.' "

Opinion:Joe Biden's VP choice of Kamala Harris signals return to American values and competence

Opinion:Why Joe Biden and Kamala Harris would be a disastrous duo in the year of George Floyd

Rep. James Clyburn, D-S.C., whose endorsement helped turn around Biden's floundering primary campaign, was another who got the early heads-up. He said keeping the news quiet from his three daughters was difficult.

"Hopefully they'll forgive me for not letting the cat out of the bag," Clyburn said with a smile in a video call with reporters Tuesday.

For Harris' part, she didn't give any public indication in the days leading up to Tuesday that she knew she was Biden's pick.

South Carolina state Rep. J.A. Moore, a supporter of Harris' primary campaign, received a call from her Sunday, but it wasn’t to talk politics, he said. Instead, she called to sing "Happy Birthday" to Moore's daughter, who had just turned 1.

“I look at her as an auntie,” Moore said, adding that they have checked in several times since the senator ended her presidential bid.

A running mate search process unlike any other

Making this vice presidential search different from others before it, Biden in March vowed to choose a woman. The vetting process was also constrained by a global pandemic, with virtual meetings replacing some that might normally occur in person.

The selection followed more than 120 hours of meetings via FaceTime between Biden's vice president selection committee co-chairs – Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester, D-Del., former Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd, Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti and Cynthia Hogan, Biden's legal counsel when he was vice president – and Democratic activists, party leaders and interests groups.

The group also met with organizations that specialize in getting women elected to office to prepare for hurdles that a male vice presidential candidate wouldn't face.

From rival to running mate:What 'fearless fighter' Kamala Harris brings to Joe Biden's ticket

Splitting into pairs, the co-chairs met virtually with an initial group of more than 20 vice presidential contenders, asking each a list of uniform questioning that included, "What would you want your agenda to be? What do you think Trump's nickname for you will be?"

Biden's selection committee submitted their findings and assessments to Biden and his wife, Dr. Jill Biden, who played a central role. The larger list was whittled to 11 finalists, who underwent a deep vetting.

"He said: ‘I’m not looking to make a demographic or a political or a geographic choice, I’m looking for the best partner in governance. I’m looking for the right vice president,' " Garcetti told USA TODAY, describing Biden's directions to kick off the nearly four-month search process. "He was very clear about that.

“Second, he was very protective about everybody in the process. He’s been through this himself. To have Joe Biden ask you to help him find a vice president is like Michael Jordan asking you to find a shooting guard to be alongside him.”

'Do not hold grudges':Biden's notes reveal several talking points about Kamala Harris

Richmond said he believes picking a woman of color went into Biden's thinking, but it wasn't the overriding consideration.

"Since George Floyd, this country has been in a real inflection point," Richmond said. "I don't think that was the major factor. But did he notice she was a woman of color? Absolutely."

Along with Harris, Demings and Duckworth, the 11 women vetted were Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, California Rep. Karen Bass, Atlanta Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms, New Mexico Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham, voting rights activist Stacey Abrams, former National Security Adviser Susan Rice, and Wisconsin Sen. Tammy Baldwin.

Although Biden never eliminated any of the 11 from consideration, he zeroed in closest on Harris, Bass, Duckworth, Whitmer and Rice, with whom he had worked in the Obama administration, according to people familiar with Biden's thinking.

Leading the vetting process was Bob Bauer, lead counsel for the Biden campaign, Lisa Monaco, President Barack Obama's former Homeland Security adviser, and Dana Remus, deputy White House counsel under Obama. More than a dozen attorneys worked pro bono to conduct a deep dive of the candidates and their backgrounds.

Biden met with all 11 candidates – some in person, others virtually – before ultimately choosing Harris, long considered one of the front-runners for the job. Among those he met in person were Rice and Whitmer. As a whole, the search committee did not make a final recommendation to Biden, but some senior campaign officials made a strong case for Harris.

"I think there's a deep bond there – of course momentarily frayed, maybe, in the the campaign," Garcetti said, referring to the desegregation attacks Harris torpedoed Biden with on the debate stage last year.

During the first Democratic debate last year, Harris went after Biden on his civil rights record and Biden touting his ability to work with Republicans, including segregationist Sens. James Eastland and Herman Talmadge. She went on to criticize his opposition to school busing in the 1970s, telling the story of a girl in California who was part of just the second integrated class in her school.

"That little girl is me," Harris said in a moment that went viral and was credited with helping give her a short-lived bump in the polls.

"He moved on from that the moment after it happened. I just kind of reminded him that I thought that they had that bond that, he's running because of Beau's memory, I think, as much as anything else," Garcetti said, referring to Biden's oldest son, who was close with Harris before his death in 2015. "And she's the one who's the quickest route to that. That can't be (overstated)."

The drama before Biden's announcement:Tense and teasing online moments lead up to Joe Biden's announcement on Kamala Harris

Like other search committee members, Garcetti said he learned Harris was the pick from Jill Biden on Tuesday – but he had a "strong sense" that was the direction in the final days. The decision became clearer when he started to get phone calls from other candidates who were just told they didn't get the nod.

"I would say sometime between Monday morning and Tuesday morning is probably when he said, 'Let's go.'"

Hours of interviews and deep dives into history

The process was grueling and at times emotional for the candidates, even more so for those who had not been through such rigorous vetting for a White House position, according to those who were close to the process. Candidates had to block off large portions of their schedules to go through every aspect of their public and private lives, often unable to rely solely on staff because many details are held only by the candidates themselves.

Some candidates reached out to members of Biden's inner circle for informal advice as they moved through the process. A source familiar with the process said several of the candidates, including Harris, talked with Sen. Chris Coons, D-Del., a longtime Biden confidante. Coons would sometimes pass along noteworthy comments to the Biden campaign after those conversations, the source said, but noted Coons would typically direct the candidates to the campaign's official channels.

Most of the women considered appeared to leave the process with a sense of gratitude and honor.

“It was amazing to be associated with all of them, and I know that all of them share the same ceiling that I do, which is deep respect and honor as having been a part of the process,” Bass told USA TODAY.

'There is no playbook':How Trump and Biden are trying to run virtual campaigns during coronavirus

After Biden called her Tuesday afternoon with the news she was not his choice, Bass said she was excited and knew Biden would pick "the strongest choice."

"I think that the vice president, having served as vice president, knows exactly who is the best person for the job, and he made that choice," Bass added.

Baldwin said she was similarly "excited" about Biden's selection. In Harris, with whom she serves in the Senate, Biden had found someone who "would be ready on Day One."

According to people familiar with the candidate meetings, the selection committee was impressed with Harris' command of issues and confidence in her ability to take on Trump. Harris also "spoke powerfully" about her friendship with Beau Biden. The two developed a bond when Harris was attorneys general in California, and Beau Biden held the same role in Delaware. Harris' personal story, the daughter of immigrants who has experienced the "American success story," resonated as well.

In the end, sources said Biden saw Harris as someone who could be a "governing partner" – much the way Biden saw his role with Obama. Biden felt a "personal connection" to Harris and saw her as experienced to serve as president if needed.

Clyburn said he'd talked with Biden more over the past four or five days "than I’ve talked to him all year."

Clyburn, the House majority whip, said he and Biden spent the calls discussing the host of candidates and their potential liabilities to his campaign. That included Harris' past as a prosecutor, Clyburn said, explaining he advised Biden that many of the attacks on past careers were unfair. Some on the left have challenged Harris' persona as a "progressive prosecutor" and argued she was on the wrong side of several policy issues as a district attorney and then California attorney general.

"I do not wish to see people's professions held against them," Clyburn said he told Biden. "This whole notion that if you become a chief of police or you become a prosecutor, you ought not be considered. People ought to be considered for how well they conduct themselves in their chosen professions. How can we ask to have police chiefs of color, prosecutors of color and then hold that against them?"

Clyburn said he did not recommend any single candidate, only offering his views on each of the finalists, who he said appeared to have narrowed down to Harris, Rice and Bass over the past two or three days.

"I said to him, 'I'm glad it was not me that had to make the choice,' " Clyburn said.

Coons, who has known Biden for at least 30 years, applauded the choice, calling Harris a "comforting and supportive" friend.

He said the campaign had looked for someone with the "experience and background" for the role, a person who, along with Biden, would be able to represent the "range and the diversity" of America, and someone with whom Biden had "simpatico," or a close relationship.

A sort-of audition process for Harris

In what proved to be auditions for vice president, Harris had a dozen Biden campaign appearances since he became the presumptive Democratic nominee, giving her a chance to stump for Biden.

On June 26, Harris participated in a virtual roundtable with Jill Biden for a Wisconsin audience to hear about President Donald Trump's efforts to invalidate the Affordable Care Act.

“Obviously, this administration is trying to take health care away from millions of Americans. That's it. It's actually not more complex than that,” Harris said. “We need what (Joe Biden) so uniquely has, which is empathy for the American people and an understanding of what suffering is like.”

A month earlier, Harris joined a Women for Biden call May 21 to discuss what was at stake for women in November. She recounted her friendship with Beau Biden and how it opened her to a different side of Joe Biden.

"I got to know (Joe) mostly as a human being and as a person, as opposed to what I knew of him as a leader – a longstanding public servant, a committed public servant," Harris said.

That's the ticket:Joe Biden picks Sen. Kamala Harris as his 2020 vice presidential running mate

How the president responded:Trump criticizes Joe Biden's VP process, saying he disagreed with pledge to consider only women

“And I'll tell you guys the kind of love, it was a very special relationship that I witnessed between a father and a son and a son and a father, both of whom were public servants."

She pointed to the "horrendous loss" and suffering Biden has endured, adding that America not only needs a president with a "lifelong commitment to public service" but someone who is compassionate and "feels a sense of responsibility" to help those in pain.

"Joe's a fighter," Harris said, sounding like a running mate back in May. "He fights for people, and that's what we need right now.”

search_result.title: Century-old Morris County iron crafting business is closing up shop
search_result.text:
BOONTON TOWNSHIP — From Prohibition-era Manhattan to its present home along the Rockaway River, Tringali Iron Works has thrived — and helped to forge local history — through the backbreaking art of metal crafting.

The family business was founded in Manhattan's Tribeca in 1923 by an immigrant blacksmith from Italy. For the last quarter-century, his grandson Bernard "Bud" Knudsen has carried on the tradition out of a 200-year-old shop on an idyllic spot here in Morris County, where the river spills over a wide, gentle waterfall.

"This location is insane," Knudsen said during a visit to the shop on North Main Street. Now, he's preparing to leave it all behind.

Story continues after gallery.

After 50 years of firing, pounding, welding and bending iron and steel into gates, fences, window guards and more, all with artistic flair, Knudsen is ready to hang up his hammer and enjoy retirement. A final sale began on Jan. 1 and will continue as long as there is leftover inventory to offer.

"I have commitments that will probably take me through the spring and into the summer, but I'm not taking on any more big jobs," said Knudsen, 65, who has already bought a retirement home in Delaware.

Tringali Iron Works put its stamp on NY history

Knudsen, a trained architect, and his cousins took over the business from his father and uncle, who had succeeded his grandfather, the ironworks' founder. Liborio Tringali was an experienced blacksmith and farrier (a craftsman who shoes horses). He took over a shop in lower Manhattan in 1923 after emigrating from Italy to Brooklyn.

One could almost trace the history of New York from the products forged by the Tringali Iron Works, which operated out of a location that was a city block in length.

Early work there included the fashioning of metal "diamond plates" to cover New York's wooden floors and prevent fires "when it was a booming industrial city," Knudsen said.

Later, in the 1940s, Tringali put up rails and fire escapes on brownstones. In the 1950s and 1960s, when the crime rate was rising, the business answered a demand for iron window bars.

World War II also brought work for the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The war was an "all-hands-on-deck" time for the entire family as Tringali pitched in to support the Allied efforts. Knudsen's mother, Jean, "became sort-of a Rosie the Riveter," he said, referring to the iconic poster that encouraged women to enter the workforce on the homefront.

During the lengthy Statue of Liberty renovation that started in 1986, Knudsen said, his was one of "maybe a hundred" metal shops contracted to work on various aspects of the project. Tringali's contribution was to create "artsy cafeteria tables" for the national park facility.

Eventually, the business thrived by manufacturing ornate tree guards for city streets, work that continues to this day.

Rockaway River paradise

After the World Trade Center bombing in 1993, Knudsen's cousins withdrew from the business, and the original shop — now a neighbor to Robert De Niro's Tribeca Films studio — was put up for sale not long before the 9/11 attacks. It was eventually purchased by "a celebrity buyer" whom Knudsen declined to name. At that point, he had begun his search for a new location across the Hudson.

"It kind of fell to me to keep it going," Knudsen said.

He found the shop's new home by accident. During one scouting trip, he was detoured from Parsippany into the Boonton area. He found his way onto North Main Street, where he discovered his future riverside paradise and bought the circa-1820 building.

Local news:Boonton Township school, town hall renovations could boost taxes almost $1,000 a year

"I just fell in love with the place," he said.

Over the years, Knudsen learned that the site had been used as an oil depot and as a factory for making buttons and munitions during the Civil War.

"You can still find buttons and bullets outside in the ground," Knudsen said.

One-of-a-kind bargains

His remaining inventory features a variety of antique metal grates, frames and window guards, including some saved from renovations of the Federal Reserve Bank in New York's Financial District. There's also a good supply of glass-and-metal artwork he has tinkered with of late, including custom "wizard sticks" — decorative staffs that "people really enjoy."

On a recent visit, a customer, Bridget Burke Weiss of Boonton, was making a return trip, shopping for an ornamental window grate for her home.

The items she bought during her previous trip, including handcrafted spinners, were intended as gifts. "But I ended up keeping them," Weiss said.

"I saw the sale sign and I was so sad, because it's such a neat space," she said. "It's magical. I hope something neat comes in here. It's got such a great vibe."

Heated metal and heavy muscle

Knudsen's main workshop is equipped with hydraulic cutting and bending machines that allowed him to shape his increasingly artistic metalcrafts without the need for heated metal and heavy muscle. The building sits on multiple stone foundations with walls as thick as 3 feet in some places.

"People always ask me about flooding," Knudsen said of his spot above the notoriously flood-prone Rockaway River. "These foundations are built right into the riverbed. So we don't get a lot of flooding. I got an inch or so during the last rainstorm, but everybody on the river does."

He still uses his grandfather's old anvil to pound certain pieces into shape. The fourth generation of the business was represented by his niece, who worked there as a welder for three years.

Now he's on his own at the shop, except for his dog and shop mascot, Paddy. The building was "put quietly on the market," Knudsen said, but has not yet been listed.

Business is still good, he added. Continuing referrals bring steady work from Manhattan, and local walk-ins commission additional projects.

But a half-century of pounding is enough for Knudsen.

"It's hard work, backbreaking work," he said. "When I realized we were coming up on 100 years, I wanted to do that. That was very special to me. But now that we made it, I'm ready to do something else."
